EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Since 1963, the City of Oregon Water Treatment Plant has used chlorine as part of its treatment process in providing safe drinking water to its consumers.  During those 36 years, we have never had an off site release.  We recognize that chlorine can be a hazardous chemical if safety precautions are not followed and we work very hard to protect our employees and our neighbors.



FACILITY DESCRIPTION

The Water Plant is designed to treat 12 million gallons per day of water drawn in from Lake Erie.  The treament plant will soon be able to treat 16 million gallons per day.  The treatment plant is a lime-caustic soda softening plant with rapid sand filters.  The chlorine is fed for disinfection  purposes from one ton containers.  The chlorine in the containers is in the liquid form under pressure and it is drawn off by vacuum as a gas.

Chlorine ton containers are transported to the plant by flat bed truck.  An overhead monorail lifts the containers off the truck and moves them to the storage building.  We receive three containers per shipment  approximately once per month.


RMP - RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

Management System - Overall responsibility of the system for the Water Plant rests with the Superintendent and Chief Operator

Employee Participation Plan - An Employee Participation Committee has been formed consisting of  Superintendent, Chief Operator, most senior Water Operator, Instrumentation Technician/Operator II, and  Water Treatment Maintenance/Operator II.   It is the committee?s responsibility to conduct the Process Hazard Analysis and implement, and review Operating Procedures and recommend modifications.

Process Safety Information - Diagrams and schematics are available and  employees have been trained and are familiar with the chlorination process.  Any new employee will be fully trained before they are expected to work with the process.

Process Hazard Analysis - The  Process Hazard Analysis is carried out by the Employee Particip

ation Committee.  The overall process is evaluated,  and possible recommendations are discussed.  A schedule is set up with completion date assigned for each task.  Follow-up meetings are conducted to check on the progress of the items  to be implemented.  The checklist method was utilized.

Operating Procedures - Operating procedures are documented using a standardized format.  Copies of procedures are given to all employees during classroom training and hands-on training.  Annually these procedures are reviewed by the Employee Participation Committee.  Any changes in procedures must follow the Management of Change requirements and  documentation  of the changes made on the Controlled  Documents.

Training - All new employees are given initial training  prior to working independently with the chlorine process.  Refresher training will be given at a minimum of every 3 years.  Maintenance/Operators will receive additional hands-on training relating to equipment repair and maintenance.  Records are kept of all training including the means to evaluate that the training was understood.

Contractor Safety - Policies are in place to evaluate contractor?s qualifications before a selection is made.  Contractors will be given orientation and training on the chlorine process their first day of work.  Records are kept of contractor injuries and illness.  This information is periodically reviewed and evaluated during the construction phase.

Pre-Startup Review - A pre-startup safety review will be performed for any  new process regulated under the RMP and any existing process with modifications significant enough to change the safety information.  Any deficiencies will have a corrective action taken before start up is attempted.

Mechanical  Integrity - An effective mechanical integrity program is integral to preventing accidental chemical releases that may result from mechanical failure.  Maintenance personnel are trained with proper maintenance techniques.  Personnel will onl

y use factory specified parts when working on chlorine equipment and adhere to required maintenance schedule.

Hot Work Permit - Maintenance personnel are trained to insure that a hot work permit is issued before any welding or torch cutting is undertaken on or near the chlorine rooms.

Management of Change -  System changes are properly reviewed against the original system design specifications.  A review must be completed for any temporary or permanent change in the chlorine process which includes replacement other than replacement in kind.

Incident Investigation - If any leak would occur, procedures are set to form a team and compile information about the incident no later than 48 hours after the report.  The results and any new recommendations must be communicated to employees and documented on operating procedures.

Emergency Planning and Response - A written emergency action plan is maintained.  Employees are given the plan and trained in the appropriate response.  There is also coordination with the Oregon and Jerusalem Fire Departments.

Compliance Audits - Compliance audits are carried out by a team comprising an outside individual knowledgeable in PSM an RMP auditing, plant superintendent and senior operator.  After the completion of the audit, employees will be notified of any recommendations and changes.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no off site consequences from the Oregon Water Treatment Plant in the last five years.  In fact, there have been no off site consequences from the Oregon Water Treatment Plant since the plant started operating in 1963.




EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Water Treatment Plant personnel are trained in the use of  a Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA).  However, our Emergency Action Plan calls for notifying  the Oregon Fire Department if the leak is anything put minor.  Both Oregon Fire Station #1 and Jerusalem Fire Department have toured the plant and are familiar with the chlorine location and process.

A drill was conducted on July 21, 1999.  It included the fire departments from Oregon and Jerusalem, St. Charles Hospital , Oregon Police and Lucas County Sheriff.  The Oregon Fire Department schedules tours of the plant routinely to familiarize its members with the process.



COMMUNICATION PROGRAM

Under the Lucas County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), a coalition of nine facilities in Lucas County covered by the RMP formed  communication and technical work groups to help each other comply with the rule and provide information to the public.  The groups started working in the  summer of 1998.  The communication group conducted a survey to determine what should be the group?s focus.  Few residents were aware of the Lucas County LEPC and they were not familiar with the concept  "shelter-in-place".  The communications group developed an LEPC brochure and folder, "shelter-in-place" refrigerator magnets, and individual facility brochures.   The media was briefed prior to a dinner given for briefing elected officials and emergency responders.   On May 15, 1999 the nine facilities set up informational booths at Franklin Park Mall and on May 16, 1999 six east side facilities set up informational booths at Oregon Fest .  On May 14, 1999 the neighbors within a mile of the plant were hand delivered  the LEPC brochure, plant brochure, emergency evacuation brochure and refrigerator magnets.   Phone numbers were provided if residents had any question.
